Title: Early Supplemental Parenteral Nutrition in Abdominal Surgery: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Background: This randomised controlled trial assessed the impact of early supplemental parenteral nutrition (E-SPN) versus late supplemental parenteral nutrition (L-SPN) on nosocomial infections in patients undergoing major abdominal surgery with high nutritional risk and poor tolerance to enteral nutrition (EN).

Methods: Conducted in 11 tertiary hospitals in China from April 1, 2017, to December 31, 2018, the trial included 230 patients with an NRS-2002 score of ≥3 and ≤30% energy intake from EN on postoperative day 2. Participants were randomised 1:1 to E-SPN (starting day 3) or L-SPN (starting day 8) groups. Randomisation used a permuted block design with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes. Outcome assessors were blinded. The primary outcome was the incidence of nosocomial infections from postoperative day 3 to discharge.

Results: Of 230 randomised, 229 were analysed (115 E-SPN, 114 L-SPN) using intention-to-treat. E-SPN significantly reduced nosocomial infections (8.7% vs 18.4%; risk difference, 9.7%; 95% CI, 0.9%-18.5%; P = 0.04). No significant differences were found in noninfectious complications (27.0% vs 33.3%; risk difference, 6.4%; 95% CI, −5.5% to 18.2%; P = 0.32) or total adverse events (65.2% vs 71.9%; risk difference, 6.7%; 95% CI, −5.3% to 18.7%; P = 0.32). Therapeutic antibiotic days were fewer in the E-SPN group (mean difference, 1.0 days; 95% CI, 0.2-1.9; P = 0.01).

Interpretation: E-SPN reduced nosocomial infections in high-risk patients post-abdominal surgery, suggesting it as a favorable strategy for those with poor EN tolerance. Trial Registration: ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier: NCT03115957. Funding: Not specified.
